From a friend's balcony in Breach Candy in Mumbai, I looked out across the bay and saw the Taj Hotel which with the train station formed, I think, the two main epicenters of the attack. My friend said without  a trace of anger that he had seen the attack and that the sound of the explosions had carried over the water. It was remarkable how normal everything seemed, I thought - with my friend and his family, the hotel on the horizon and with the city of Mumbai itself. Busy and yet relaxed, there was no sign of anxiety or of hypervigilance in Mumbai. The city's pluralism, its economic vitality, civil society, none of these appeared diminished. It may be that what societies do to themselves and others in the wake of terrorist attacks is as destructive as the attack itself.  That may well be the aim of terrorism. Perhaps, too, different cultures respond to catastrophes in different ways.

I've always read Mr. Church's reply differently from Mr. Kaplan's interpretation. I don't know which of us is right, but I believe that the reply can be read in two ways.

"Yes, Virginia" asserts that Santa Claus exists whether or not we see him; that all the skeptics of a skeptical age might try in vain to prove that he does not exist, and yet fail. Mr. Kaplan focuses on the need for wonder and delight in what would otherwise be a dreary world, and concludes that Santa Claus exists because we want him to exist; that his existence is the product of our desire for such a figure to transcend reason and practicality, and give us, just for a moment, the world we wish to live in. But I think this is a simplistic interpretation; and perhaps even a cynical one, for it seems to conclude that Santa Claus is basically wishful thinking.

The second, and I think subtler interpretation, is hinted at when Mr. Church says that Santa Claus "exists as certainly as love and generosity and devotion exist . . ." Santa Claus does not exist merely because we wish him to, but because we make him exist. Mr. Church did not say whether Santa Claus was flesh and blood. I think that he found that question both unanswerable and irrelevant. Even if there were no person named Santa Claus, our love and generosity and devotion would make him exist.

While I can only hope that he might be a person I could one day meet, I know that Santa Claus exists, because he lives in our hearts.

"First, why did Mr. Putin do something so stupid? Second, why were so many influential people in the United States impressed by and envious of his stupidity?"

To answer both questions, the people involved still believe in the logic of empire by armed conquest. They are impressed by feats of prowess, be they one person's potent physique or a community's consequential conquests. Putin may be a rival, but he operates in a way they understand and appreciate.

They are less impressed by the fiddly bits of bureaucracy, money or science, even though all three are necessary to keep our modern society humming and hopefully improving. They don't often udnerstand or appreciate these things. It's the age-old tension between action-minded generals and cautious bureaucrats.

Put it together, and you have the basis for our warmongering and our admiration for muscle-bound thugs. More's the pity.

Santa Claus unraveled for me when I was four and five. That first year, I doubted Santa's omniscience when he wrapped a warning around a rock and left it in the chimney. The warning was for not only my sister, who had been doing her classic "mean girl" bit, but for me as well, when I was 99% sure that I had done nothing that would put me on the naughty list, if only the adults had seen what actually transpired. The next year, in early December I found the doll clothes that would appear with my stocked as "from Santa." I knew then, but I kept my mouth shut because it seemed so important to my parents that I keep believing.

Today I believe because that belief makes my world sweeter. My husband and I discussed this very issue earlier today. I want to believe. I read "Flight of the Reindeer" and imagine how reindeer can fly. I listen for feet on the roof. I like the innocent wonder.

When I want to break briefly from a comment I copy the whole thing and it stays in the clipboard ready to be pasted if necessary.

One of the reasons I prefer a PC over a Mac is that the former has "Notebook." It's magical in that when you copy anything you've entered in Notebook it automatically changes from its ASCII format to the format of the document into which you paste it. This is particularly helpful if you are copying something from the Internet into, say, an e-mail. As I am a sloppy typist (or should I say keyboardist) I often use it to compose my comments as I have been known to inadvertantly hit a key that takes me to another page. In Mac there is a seemingly similar feature but it keeps the original format.
